Systems where suitable: Mixed irrigated, Mixed rainfed, Rangeland, Intensive confined systems
Description and implementation constrain: Raising multiple animal species within the same farming system. This strategy aims to achieve a variety of benefits, such as risk mitigation, economic stability, resource optimization, and lower environmental impact. Instead of focusing exclusively on one species, farmers diversify by incorporating different types of livestock. Species diversification is typically constrained by labor, and knowledge.

Systems where suitable: Mixed irrigated, Mixed rainfed, Rangeland, Intensive confined systems
Description and implementation constrain: Switching from one species to another within the same farming system. This can increase resilience (e.g., switching from cattle to more drought-tolerant species such as goats, sheep and camels), reduce farm emissions (e.g., moving from ruminant species to pigs or poultry), and speed up household cash turn-over (e.g., move from large animals to small animals that can be purchased or sold easily in response to a cash squeeze), for example. This option may be constrained by labor, knowledge, and cost.

Implementation of advanced practices to enhance the quality and efficiency of the forages and supplements provided to animals and improve their nutrition. This approach aims to improve animal health, productivity, and overall farm sustainability. This option is typically constrained by availability of forages and supplements (especially during the dry season), labor, knowledge, and cost.

Management of pasture and grazing lands to optimize the utilization of forages and promote sustainable and efficient livestock production. This approach involves various techniques and principles aimed at maximizing the benefits of grazing for both the livestock and the land. Improved grazing includes rotational grazing, grazing planning, rest periods, species selection, water management, fencing and infrastructure, and monitoring of animal movements in the farm. Land tenure, labor, and knowledge can be important constraints to scaling of improved grazing, as is cost.

Adjusting herd size to adapt to seasonal changes in feed supply. Build up herd sizes in recovery periods to prevent total loss of herd during drought. During drought, culling of weaker animals for food and cash needs. Constraints include market accessibility, price fluctuations, socio-cultural considerations. Herd recovery in more arid environments can take many years.

Systematic handling, treatment, and utilization of animal manure in agricultural and livestock operations. It involves implementing practices to effectively manage and capitalize on the nutrient-rich organic material produced by animals. Whereas labor is the main constraint for manure management, cost and knowledge can also be important bottlenecks. In Eastern Africa, for example, manure disposal is a complex problem as animals produce more manure than can be recycled in the surrounding agricultural areas.

Systems where suitable: Mixed irrigated, Mixed rainfed, Rangeland, Intensive confined systems
Description and implementation constrain: Increasing access of livestock to water and improving the efficiency with which it is used. Examples include rain water harvesting in ponds and digging a well to exploit ground water. Constraints include cost, land tenure, labor and maintenance of ponds or wells.

Systems where suitable: Mixed irrigated, Mixed rainfed, Rangeland, Intensive confined systems
Description and implementation constrain:
Selectively bred varieties of animals within the livestock industry. These breeds are often created with specific goals in mind, such as improved productivity, adaptability to certain environments, disease resistance, or the enhancement of desirable traits for agricultural purposes. Accessibility, cost, and knowledge often preclude widespread adoption of new breeds for livestock farmers with limited financial resources. Read more about livestock breeding in this article collection https://hdl.handle.net/10568/41914 . 
This option can also include the use of "unimproved" breeds that have desirable traits, such as trypanotolerance in cattle. In Africa there is considerable unexploited genetic variation in indigenous breeds that could be utilised by farmers, though limited information accessibility and cost are major constraints.

Rehabilitate and improve the ecological health and productivity of natural rangeland ecosystems. Strategies for rangeland restoration include vegetation management, grazing management, water management, soil conservation, invasive species control, wildlife habitat restoration, and community engagement. Bottlenecks for scaling rangeland restoration include cost and knowledge. Learn about CGIAR's rangeland restoration work using participatory rangeland management (PRM) at https://hdl.handle.net/10568/136023 .

Integrate trees, forages, and livestock in a mutually beneficial manner within a single land management unit. These systems are designed to optimize the ecological, economic, and social functions of both forestry and livestock components. Silvopastoral systems could increase productivity, decrease GHG emissions, improve carbon storage potential and aid adaptation to heat stress. The scalability of silvopastoral systems has been limited by several factors including knowledge, cost, and land tenure. Read more about silvopastoral systems implementations here (https://hdl.handle.net/10568/125046 ), and about their key environmental benefits here (https://doi.org/10.3389/fsufs.2021.742842 ).

Systems where suitable: Mixed irrigated, Mixed rainfed, Rangeland, Intensive confined systems
Description and implementation constrain: In rangelands and the mixed systems, involvement in market-based schemes for water, carbon, biodiversity and tourism, to diversify income sources (payment for ecosystem services, PES). Constraints include the challenges of monitoring, land tenure, knowledge.

Systems where suitable: Mixed irrigated, Mixed rainfed, Rangeland, Intensive confined systems
Description and implementation constrain: Data, forecasts, and actionable advisory based on short-term weather patterns and longer-term seasonal climate outlooks. This information is crucial for livestock farmers to anticipate and manage feed and water during drought and heat stress events, disease management and access to veterinary advice, water resource management for grazing areas, market planning, and emergency preparedness. Access and knowledge to use weather information are the most critical bottlenecks for scaling. CGIAR's work on climate services is extensive, covering over 15 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, using methodologies such as the Multidisciplinary Working Groups (https://hdl.handle.net/10568/113733 ), Participatory Integrated Climate Services for Agriculture (https://hdl.handle.net/10568/134781 ), the Shamba Shape Up (https://hdl.handle.net/10568/126423 ), amongst other digital and participatory channels.

Systems where suitable: Mixed irrigated, Mixed rainfed, Rangeland, Intensive confined systems
Description and implementation constrain: Risk management tool that uses specific weather-related indices as triggers to compensate livestock producers for losses incurred due to adverse weather conditions. Unlike traditional insurance, which requires individual assessment of losses, index-based insurance simplifies the claims process by linking payouts to predefined weather parameters. Automated payouts reduce transaction cost and enhance transparency. Index-based insurance is mainly constrained by cost and knowledge especially related to financial literacy and record keeping. Read more about index-based insurance for livestock (IBLI) and its impacts at https://hdl.handle.net/10568/630 .
